This could be done, but requires some integration around discovery and maybe some protocol extension to handle some aspects of. In rough terms, I could envision it like this, given two devices A and B and a relay R;
- A connects to R
- R sets up a listening port that is specific to A, and announces this to the announce server
- B looks up A in the announce server, and gets the address to the above port on R
- B connects to R
- R shuffles bytes to and fro so that A talks directly to B

Maybe, possibly, this could be done without any changes by just writing up R correctly. It can't respond to A when it connects, because it has no (correct) certificate to offer, so probably A will timeout and reconnect repeatedly. This may be fine.

The first step ("A connects to R") would need to be either by manual configuration or something else, since R hasn't announced for B at that point...
Btw, in case both nodes can do manual configuration towards the given relay, then the relay in question is like 15 lines of code.

I've been looking into this problem and my thought it is extend the protocol and allow a device (A) to communicate to device (B) via a intermediary device (R) that is trusted by both device A and B. My thought is that device R will relay a raw TLS encrypted packets that are destined for device B. This might not be as simple as I think it will be because I don't know how easy it will be to negotiate the connections and such over this relaying mechanism. When I get a spare moment (and go through and understand the syncthing code), I'm going to try to throw something together.

@prestonwii It's doable. The proxy could be simple enough to just tie two incoming TCP connections together. The problem you run into is mentioned above - the TLS negotiation isn't symmetric, so two syncthing's both connecting out won't be able to talk to each other, one of them should play the "server" role (accepting the connection). This could be worked around by a config on syncthing to switch the roles around, i.e. connect out to the proxy but from a TLS point of view pretend the connection was incoming. In that scenario one of the devices need to be aware that there is a proxy involved and be configured to play the server role; the other device would not need to know and would just connect to the proxy as usual.

Those were pretty much my thoughts, one syncthing instance would connect to the relay (or proxy) and tell it that it wants to relay the connection to another device. If the relay device is configured to trust the other device (and already has a connection to it), we can create a connection to that device. It would result in two TLS connections, one between device A to device R and one between device R and device B. Device A is aware of the relay and device B doesn't need to be aware of it (but still could be). I think I'm going to have to play around with code to figure things out. Do you have any sample code for things you've already tried so I can get a good idea on where to start?

Actually I wasn't thinking of anything as advanced as that, although it would be nice as it sounds like you may not have to configure the proxy specifically (if the devices tell it who they want to talk to etc). I don't have any relevant code here, sorry. :/

I'm close to having something working and basically I've settled on opening another port for relaying. After connecting to the port, the device will request a relay be created to a particular device ID. If the relay host is familiar with both the connecting host and the host that the connecting host is requesting a relay to, the connection will revert to a relay connection which we should be able to use as a connection for inserting into the model and getting a functioning protocol connection.

I've got this working now for trusted devices and they can connect to each other through another Syncthing node via another port (defaults to 22001). The problem that I'm having now that is a trust relationship for allowing others to relay through a Syncthing node is non-existent and it presents a variety of security issues. At the moment, the relay will take a DeviceID, look it up in its list of connected devices, and then set up the relay if it knows about the device. So the trust relationship is the fact that the relay device is connected to it and the device is part of its configuration. Removing this check, opens up the relay system to basically any traffic because there is no way to establish a trust relationship with another Syncthing device short of entering the DeviceID manually.
syncthing is unusable for me without this.

I had something that worked, but it was of questionable value because it basically allowed connections to hosts, but it required a host that it could already connect to (making the relay kind of pointless). What is really needed, I think, is a global relay system, or the ability to allow others to relay via someone else (a non-trusted device, basically). The problem with this method is that it opened up a number of security issues that could have allowed spammers to basically get an open relay via a syncthing device. I was working on a method to verify syncthing hosts before creating the relay, but I started making a new protocol for verification, which I don't think would be a welcome change when it could be added to the standard protocol.

issue.title: Allow nodes to behave as transfer nodes only.
issue.body:
It would be nice if a node can act as transfer node only.

Example:
- RaspberryPI with limited disk space, e.g. a 32Gb SD
- Two laptops which need to be in sync but they meet online infrequently.
- Laptop 1 syncs with RaspberryPI
- Later RaspberryPi syncs with Laptop 2. 
- Once all nodes are in sync, the transfer node (i.e. RaspberryPi) deletes all files freeing the used space but still reports as being synced.
